channel.title: First Program
channel.description:
Just a basic Area calculation program, read how to make text and if statements in Python. Ended up with this. [code=python]print "Welcome to the Area Calculation Program!" print "----------------------------------------" print
#Get menu print "What type of shape are you wanting to get the area of?" print "1 = Rectangle" print "2 = Circle"
shape = input("> ")
if shape == 1: length = input("Enter the length: ") width = input("Enter the width: ") area = length*width print "The area is", area print else: radius = input("Enter the radius: ") area = 3.14*(radius**2) print "The area is", area print
feedback = input("Hope this helped, leave some feedback (1-10): ")
if feedback <= 7: print "I will try to improve!" else: print "Glad I could help!"[/code]
Judging on what I currently know, which is little to none, where do the rest of you consider I start learning from here? e.g A book, ebook, online tutorials, specific URL you've learned from, etc. I'm currently trying to prepare for college going into the CS field. Not sure on computer programming yet, just wanted to give it a little practice to touch up on it.

item.title: First Program
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“ISUB, post:71, topic:548069”]Even though this post has became mainly on Ashi’s hatred, I would like to show a quickidy quick program I made after reading on if statements in Java.

import java.util.Scanner;

class apples {
	private static Scanner temp;

	public static void main(String[] args){
		temp = new Scanner(System.in);
		System.out.println("What is your vaginal temperature: ");
		
		double pregnant = temp.nextDouble();
		
		if(pregnant >= 101.2){
			System.out.println("You are pregnant.");
			
		}else{
			System.out.println("The test came up false.");
		}
	}
}

Asks what the vag temp is and states whether the person is pregnant or not, of course it was just for fun and obviously not at all how they determine pregnancy.

OP: I have no idea what to learn, or in what order because of everybody’s different ideas.[/quote]

You can do something in Java nicely for a legit pregnancy test.

Read full topic

item.title: First Program
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

ISUB: Using JFrame and Graphics (Because this requires no other setup and is easy to use.), make a game. Sure this is beyond your scope at the moment, but you will quickly know what to learn by seeing what you don’t know.

Read full topic

Asks what the vag temp is and states whether the person is pregnant or not, of course it was just for fun and obviously not at all how they determine pregnancy.

Out of curiosity, what do you have?

i will go out like jesus - a martyr for the greater good

lisp isn’t exactly the best tool to write a game server in, though this doesn’t imply it’s a shit tool.
[/quote]
Write something that reads the newer version cache in lisp.[/quote]
I bet I can write a better calculator or list/ tree transversal/manipulator in a functional programming language than in (I assume) Java. A language is a tool, a hammer is not better than a saw for all tasks.

item.title: First Program
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:62, topic:548069”][quote author=Tree link=topic=666975.msg4460480#msg4460480 date=1417312029]
A language is simply a tool. You use the right tool for the job.
You shouldn’t be claiming that a language sucks. You should instead be saying that this particular tool isn’t the one that best fits the requirements. If it was so black and white, CS students would only be learning one language. You can link any list you want, it doesn’t matter. There’s going to be arguments on both sides.
[/quote]
Exactly, there are much better tools out there![/quote]

For what, this particular task? Yeah, obviously.
For every task out there? No.

I’m not going to continue this. You should know this. It’s not a difficult concept to pick up.

Read full topic

item.title: First Program
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:1, topic:548130”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=666975.msg4460388#msg4460388 date=1417285978]

I know it does, but someone suggested C/C++ was more difficult (less user friendly) than Java would be at the start.

Nawwww just jump into C. Then move onto Java.

Also Lisp is total shit. Forget it’s existence!

OP, you should follow this^ advice if you want to grow up to be a dumb, uneducated fanboy who doesn’t appreciate beauty in prog langs.

Do you even know lisp?? I can give you a list of why it’s rubbish.

http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?WhyWeHateLisp

god i hate people like you
[/quote]
Shouldn’t be talking about God like that.[/quote]

Instead of blindly assuming that you are all-knowledgable and everybody else is not, why not present viewpoints that actually make sense? Dumb fatass hipster.

Lisp is:

  • From the 50s, and still alive today as much as it was back in the day. That certainly means something, if its popularity has been “barely alive” ever since it was created.
  • Able to solve problems in a way most other languages can’t, due to its syntax (which is basically the same as its AST). Certainly a pretty unique thing.
  • Beautiful. Well, this is subjective. I don’t like looking at terribly long functions either, and macros can get ugly. But anyway, also no syntax unless you let yourself get caught-up in the parentheses (which only happens if you use a shitty-ass editor (hint: read my signature)).
  • Extensive. Macros. Look at applications of some dialects, e.g. ELisp (which is shitty, but so what? Refer to sig.)

Lisp does suck in many ways though, but so does every language. All language designers understand the tradeoffs whenever making a decision on some language feature. But yeah, massive diversity of dialects (although this isn’t necessarily a bad thing, but it does split the community), and having subpar libraries because there are less users (compared to other languages, evidently) to create them. Although this is only my opinion, and applies mainly to CL and non-Racket Schemes. Clojure obviously has all the libraries.

If you want to actually discuss about some of the opinions in that article, list some of the ones you actually agree with. I’m not an expert by all means but I’ll gladly give my input if you want.

Read full topic
